message_1:
What is the theoretical yield of carbon dioxide gas when 10 grams of sodium bicarbonate reacts with excess hydrochloric acid according to the following balanced chemical equation: 
NaHCO3 + HCl â†’ NaCl + CO2 + H2O
(Atomic masses: Na = 23, H = 1, C = 12, O = 16, Cl = 35.5)
message_2:
To calculate the theoretical yield of CO2, we first need to determine the number of moles of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) in the 10 grams given.

The molar mass of NaHCO3 is:
Na = 23 g/mol
H = 1 g/mol
C = 12 g/mol
O = 16 g/mol (x3 for three oxygen atoms)

Molar mass of NaHCO3 = 23 + 1 + 12 + (16 x 3) = 84 g/mol

Now, we can determine the moles of NaHCO3:
moles of NaHCO3 = mass / molar mass = 10 g / 84 g/mol = 0.119 moles

The balanced chemical equation shows that 1 mole of NaHCO3 reacts to produce 1 mole of CO2. Therefore, the moles of CO2 produced will be equal to the moles of NaHCO3.

moles of CO2 = 0.119 moles

Now, we can calculate the mass of CO2 produced using the molar mass of CO2:
C = 12 g/mol
O = 16 g/mol (x2 for two oxygen atoms)

Molar mass of CO2 = 12 + (16 x 2) = 44 g/mol

Mass of CO2 = moles of CO2 x molar mass of CO2 = 0.119 moles x 44 g/mol = 5.24 g

The theoretical yield of carbon dioxide gas is 5.24 grams.
